page.title: 02WOODLANDS
page.content: WOODLANDS AND SMALL COPSES ARE SCATTERED THROUGHOUT THE AREA. A FEW LARGE HOUSES ARE ON THE SOUTH FACING SLOPE AND THESE ARE SURROUNDED BY THEIR OWN TREE COVERED GARDENS. TREES OF OAK, BEECH, SYCAMORE, ASH ,WITH CONIFERS OF MORE EXOTIC SPECIES IN MINORITY. SPECIES OF LARCH, PINES, CEDARS, FIRS ARE MOST COMMON. THE LARGEST AREA OF WOODLAND (APPROX. 150 ACRES) BELONGS TO TRACEY HOUSE AND IS OF BROADLEAVED SPECIES. THE PARKLAND SURROUNDING THE HOUSE HAS CEDARS, PINES, WELLINGTONIAS, AND OTHERS OF 80 TO 100 YEARS OLD. CERTAIN TREES IN HONITON HAVE PRESERVATION ORDERS. THE FARMERS INTERVIEWED WERE MOSTLY INTERESTED IN WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ON THEIR FARMS. SOME HAVE SMALL COPSES THAT THEY LEAVE FOR WILDLIFE. MOST ONLY CUT DEAD OR DYING TREES FOR FIREWOOD.
